Luigi Lauro wrote:

> I have yet to find a way to test JNLP classes INSIDE an IDE without 
> requiring a full
> deployment, and have yet to find how can I do some automated testing 
> with JUnit for these
> classes as well.
> 
> This is my problem :)

I need to tell you that I have /no/ experience with JNLP applications, 
so this is all theory, but it could help.

What you describe about JNLP sounds much like my experience with EJB 
2.0. My preferred solution is to design EJBs to be very thin layers 
around POJOs, so thin that the EJB (extending SessionBean, for example), 
only does JNDI lookups and delegate to the resulting objects. No 
testable logic at all.

Could you do the same with your JNLP classes? I assume you need to hook 
into the JNLP framework, either by extending classes or implementing 
interfaces. Couldn't you make those extensions dumb delegaters to plain 
Java objects? Then you could test everything /except/ the JNLP wiring as 
normal.

Many people had trouble using this technique with EJB 2.0, because every 
example they ever saw suggested they put all their logic directly into 
their session bean implementations--indeed, that was the point--so it 
takes time to realize that this extra layer of indirection is worth the 
effort, and indeed in some cases, isn't worth the effort! Still, I think 
it's a technique you can try.

Good luck.
